10/10 In most of above measures, states have led the way, Centre should follow with adequate fiscal support as revenue shortfall hits states much harder and they have harder fiscal constraints. More to follow on whether we can "afford" all of above and more.

9/10 Universal basic services: Time is right for long-planned increases in health and education budgets, regularising front-line workers (ASHAs, helpers, anganwadis) and other contractual employees creating good jobs in process. See here for proposal: https://t.co/2tDzTnJkkG
8/10 Urban employment guarantee:  Pilot scheme covering half of all urban casual workers would cost around INR 50,000 cr. See here for more: https://t.co/7IfXWnYYOk

7/10 Pensions: At least a doubling of funding to Rs 20,000 crores for NSAP. Amounts too low (Rs 200 pm), stagnant for years. Poor compensation for lifetime in informal work. Centre contribution should be at least 500 pm or total allocation of 20,000 cr (was 9,000 cr last year).

6/10 Direct cash: Transfer Rs 6000 for three months to as many households as can be reached with existing infra.  Low-middle income countries have done cash transfers of 46% of GDP per capita per month over three months, last year. India's direct cash support falls far short.

5/10 PDS - At least 10% increase on last year’s budget.  Alongside, MGNREGA, has been the major source of support for vulnerable households. Absolute number of persons covered by NFSA ration cards is 81 cr. Updated to the 2020 population, the coverage should be 92 cr.

4/10 MGNREGA: At least maintain increased allocation of 1 lakh crores for 2021-22.  It has been vital social safety net for rural residents as well as returning migrants. Demand for work continues to remain significantly higher than comparable periods for last year.

3/10 Direct fiscal response (as opposed to credit and other liquidity based measures) conservative thus far; smaller than comparable developing countries. If action not taken we may face long-term productivity, human capital deficiencies in the years to come.

2/10 Background: Surveys reveal massive job, income losses for the vast majority of workers. MSMEs hit hard and liquidity-based support has not done the trick. Likely long-run effects of depleted savings, sale of assets, increased debt, reduced nutrition plus schooling, health.

1/10 #UnionBudget - what should we do to address unprecedented economic and humanitarian crisis? Key measures: MGNREGA, PDS, pensions, direct cash support, UEG, UBS; will prevent hunger, reduce indebtedness, increase demand, restore MSME incomes. Details 👇

9. Crowding out of private investment is not a problem because private investment is very unlikely to lead the recovery, it will likely follow. If borrowing not possible and monetising considered extreme, do it with clear signal that it is a one-time measure. 10/10

8. This considerably expands the fiscal deficit, but without this, a large(r) GDP contraction is possible (not to mention the human costs), which will substantially increase the debt-to-GDP ratio. Instead allowing expansion now with clear path to reduction later is better. 9/10

7. Going to 5% makes addl 6 lakh crores available for the above measures. Enough to make a big difference and make recovery a real thing. Waiting for pandemic to subside is not an option because the time frame is long and much more suffering will result from inaction today. 8/10

6. We are, even now, at only around 2% of GDP in terms of direct additional fiscal support (centre plus state). States do not have much room (GST plus other woes) but are trying anyway since they are on the frontlines. 7/10

5. All of the above will inject much needed demand (in addition to providing immediate relief). This demand is the only way incomes will revive for microenterprises. So direct additional spending *now* makes humanitarian sense and economic sense. 6/10
4. Universalise PDS, most states are expanding beyond NFSA lists, but procurement of grain is still an issue. Surplus food stocks should be used *now*, when there is urgent need. 5/10

3. Introduce an urban public works programme with a wide variety of works in municipal, health, education, and other basic urban services. Several states are experimenting with such programmes, but fiscal space is truly there only at the Centre. 4/10

2. Expand MGNREGA to 150 days (act already allows for this) and increase programme wages to state minimum wages everywhere. Surveys indicate a large unmet demand for MGNREGA work. Programme budget will need to expand significantly to make it actually demand driven. 3/10

1. Undertake as wide a cash transfer programme as possible, of INR 6000 (50% of GDP per capita) for three months. Do not limit to Jan Dhan holders, but use every possible way to reach vulnerable households. Several low-middle income countries have already done this. 2/10

8/8 Lastly, the rise of Hindutva in mainstream politics has made it all the more urgent to reimagine peoples' knowledge traditions as a way to a just and prosperous society. A point made by this article from over ten years ago: https://t.co/484Gf3MNaI

7/8 It is not India, but Latin American societies such as Bolivia and Ecuador that have gone the farthest in recent years on trying to reimagine the good life (buen vivir) in non-Eurocentric terms. But we, in India, have rich traditions of our own to construct such visions.

6/8 What it means to be "educated" or "uneducated", caste-based knowledge, Eurocentrism, are all part of the debate as I show in this essay on three books - biography of JC Kumarappa, Ilaiah's Post-Hindu India and Sousa Santos' Epistemologies of the South https://t.co/4HaM3xG68N

5/8 Lokavidya refers to open-ended knowledge in society that is produced in course of ordinary life, that forms a mainstay of thought and action for majority of people. It includes but goes far beyond technical skills to values, ethics, governance, vision of the good life etc.

4/8 The informal economy is a rich repository of lokavidya and workers routinely labeled "unskilled" due to lack of education are paradigmatic producers, teachers, and learners of this knowledge as I argue in this essay: https://t.co/JkBx8LGEfn
3/8 Our thesis is that radical, pro-people transformation of society is not possible without challenging knowledge hierarchies and restoring legitimacy to peoples' own knowledge systems.
2/8 As part of @vidyaashram98 (https://t.co/mimjqi4h47) we have been working on the radical political and economic potential of lokavidya for many years. E.g https://t.co/IKlvdUxNvq

2/9 Supply-side constraints of long-run nature remain, viz. productivity loses from poor and unreliable infrastructure, regulatory demands (predatory rather than enabling regulation).

6/6 In other words no VIP lanes, queues, toilets and what not. This experience can help in having a reality check on policy ideas. And a real world sense of actually existing admin capacity.

5/6 We cannot rush to make vital goods contingent on this capacity. It will let us down badly (as has often happened with Aadhaar already). To prevent this from happening, it is imperative that policy-makers have recent experience of ordinary peoples' lives.

4/6 Low admin capacity and high bureaucratic requirements is a dangerous combo. With our recent programmes and policies we have been tending towards this direction. We should remember that we are still a relatively low income, admin capacity constrained, society.

3/6 That is, it is better to have many people wrongly included rather than have a few wrongly excluded for lack of admin capacity. And where exclusion errors can be large, while inclusion errors likely tiny and the cost of exclusion very large (#NRC), it is really not advised.

2/6 High admin capacity societies can afford to have high bureaucratic reqs, some choose to, some not, depending on cultural, historical factors. Low admin capacity societies tend to have low bureaucratic reqs. Because exclusion errors are generally worse than inclusion errors.

1/6 On #CAA_NRC #NPR #Aadhar etc. Bureaucratic requirements and administrative capacity should generally be closely matched, and co-evolve. A large gap between the two, spells potential disaster, esp. where bureaucratic reqs pertain to food, water, shelter, citizenship etc.
